(Norton, $32.95.) Trevelyan (1876-1962), a Cambridge historian and Whig aristocrat, hoped to see decent liberal values established in Europe in the 20th century, but lived to see them disappear everywhere.  THE INNER SIDE OF THE WIND: Or, the Novel of Hero and Leander, by Milorad Pavic. (Knopf, $22.) A retelling of the ancient myth in which a brutal coincidence of time connects two stories set centuries apart.  THE INVENTION OF TRUTH, by Marta Morazzoni. (Knopf, $18.) An absorbing novella about artists and lookers at art; it concerns John Ruskin and 300 women working on the Bayeux Tapestry.  LENIN'S TOMB: The Last Days of the Soviet Empire, by David Remnick. (Random House, $25.) Decline and fall, observed by a Washington Post reporter in the Soviet Union, 1988-91.  LIFE'S DOMINION: An Argument About Abortion, Euthanasia, and Individual Freedom, by Ronald Dworkin. (Knopf, $23.) Mr. Dworkin contends that the relevant choices proceed from the idea that life is sacred, and that therefore the state must not interfere.  NIGHTMARE ON WALL STREET: Salomon Brothers and the Corruption of the Marketplace, by Martin Mayer. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A history of the investment firm, with an emphasis on its transgressions in the 1980's and 1990's.  ORDINARY TIME: Cycles in Marriage, Faith, and Renewal, by Nancy Mairs. (Beacon, $20.) An account of spiritual growth and discovery by the author of "Remembering the Bone House."  THE PUGILIST AT REST: Stories, by Thom Jones. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) A collection of short stories that portray prizefighters and war heroes surviving, but just barely.  SPY TRADER: Germany's Devil's Advocate and the Darkest Secrets of the Cold War, by Craig R. Whitney. (Times Books/Random House, $25.) The story of an East German lawyer who acted as middleman for the exchange of political prisoners during the cold war.  TINTIN IN THE NEW WORLD: A Romance, by Frederic Tuten. (Morrow, $22.) An American novelist introduces a French comic strip hero to the temptations of the real world.

nytimes_articles.headline: Style, Substance Make Memorable Meals
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE recent opening in Westport of Restaurant Zanghi -- on the ground floor of an 1873 Italianate building being converted to the Inn at National Hall -- adds a seductively elegant dimension to dining out in what has long been a good restaurant town.    The high ceiling, elaborately decorated space has three adjoining dining areas, each with soft green couches and chairs and well-spaced tables with green Art Nouveau-style vases.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pakistanis in Somalia Showed Restraint
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Bloody Sunday in Somalia" (editorial, June 15) raises important ideas on collective security and the future role of United Nations peacekeeping operations, particularly in an era that is likely to be characterized by increasing demands and expectations of United Nations peacekeeping, without a corresponding assurance of availability of resources.   Less commendable are the conclusions you appear to have somewhat hastily drawn from events that occurred in Mogadishu June 13. The loss of life is deeply deplored by everyone, especially the United Nations peacekeepers. The Security Council, basing its judgment on authentic United Nations reports from Mogadishu, has underlined that:

nytimes_articles.headline: A Therapist-Author Shuns the Limelight
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AMY BLOOM is a presence: statuesque and poised, with dark almond eyes topped by strong, arched eyebrows, her luminous face framed by a raven bob.

She speaks in a velvety contralto that a diva might envy, a voice graced by intelligence, wit and candor. She looks and sounds like someone born to be in the limelight. The surprise is that she has chosen to avoid it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giving the Boot To Soccer Critic
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   Even though Richard Sandomir admits a certain "xenophobia," his lack of understanding concerning American soccer fans' appreciation of the game borders on offensive ("Soccer and Television Make a Bad Sports Mix," The Times, June 15). First of all, "continuous play without commercials" is hardly a "revolutionary . . . big innovation." Soccer fans have been frustrated for decades missing live play during commercials of N.A.S.L. and World Cup matches while scrambling to find the same game on non-English speaking telecasts. Also by the nature of continuous play, virtually every soccer telecast is guaranteed to be under two hours.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Chinese Yearn for 'Beautiful' U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the hogs outside grunted their protests at the drizzle, R. T. Liang sipped cheap tea from one of his set of cracked cups and spoke of the Beautiful Country with a reverence that Americans might find both flattering and unsettling.   "The United States -- what a place!" Mr. Liang said wistfully, as family members clustered around him in his home, next to a porcelain God of Wealth apparently erected less in gratitude than in hope. "It's so rich! If there weren't restrictions, everybody would leave here. We would go to look for work in America, Hong Kong or Taiwan. If we could figure out how to get there, we would all go. The villages would become empty."

nytimes_articles.headline: Hail, Yankees
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   While you continue to publish article after article about how bad the Mets are this year, have you noticed that the Yankees have an interesting, above-.500 team that actually has a shot at a division title? Just thought I'd point it out. BRUCE FOX Jericho, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patriots' Russell Stable After Stabbing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Also at Boston's Massachusetts General Hospital, New England Patriots running back LEONARD RUSSELL was in stable condition after he and teammate TIM EDWARDS were stabbed in a dispute outside a nightclub early Friday. Edwards, who had come to Russell's aid in the incident, was treated for a minor wound and released. Russell was stabbed in the chest during an argument with two men. PATRICK FORTE, the Patriots vice president of football operations, was optimistic that both players would be ready for the start of training camp July 15.(AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Houses From Hartford's Greener Era
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE corner of Sisson and Farmington Avenues in Hartford has become frumpy over the last century. Elm-shaded mansions have given way to a submarine-sandwich franchise, a drugstore and monolithic apartment buildings, candy wrappers whirl across the street in the hot summer wind and even pigeons hurry by. From that vantage point at least, it's hard to believe Mark Twain once called Hartford "a vision of refreshing green." In fact, after his first visit in 1868 to see his publisher, Twain said, "You do not know what beauty is if you have not been here."    He went home to Buffalo, but remained smitten. Two years later Twain, whose real name was Samuel L. Clemens, decided to transplant himself and his bride to Nook Farm, Hartford's socially progressive settlement of literary figures and philanthropists, which included the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," Harriet Beecher Stowe.

nytimes_articles.headline: In This Dream Station Future and Past Collide
nytimes_articles.abstract: Already, it is a landmark: that soaring arch of white steel, rising above granite walls of classical Beaux-Arts grandeur. Depicted in architect's renderings with sunlight streaming through its sparkling glass skin, the arch brings out the primal emotions aroused by the sight of a rainbow after a storm. It may be years before this vision materializes. The $315 million needed to build it is not yet in hand. But Amtrak's proposal to resurrect Pennsylvania Station from a pit beneath Madison Square Garden and enshrine it within the landmark general post office building across the street has aroused more anticipation than any civic project in years.   No wonder, for this project pushes some of the hottest buttons in architecture and urbanism today. Public space. Infrastructure. Mass transit. Regional planning. But the hottest button of all is one that touches off a painful memory: the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station station 30 years ago. The razing of this station, McKim, Mead & White's 1910 masterpiece of Beaux-Arts design, was one of the greatest traumas New York City ever suffered. Public reaction was profound, and in some ways beneficial. Historical preservation was transformed from a genteel pastime to a nationwide movement with political clout. Architects began to admit that the Modern movement was turning out to be less than a boon for cities. Above all, New Yorkers began to assert a proprietary interest in the city as their collective cultural heritage.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Bosnian Crisis To All-Out War
nytimes_articles.abstract: The horror in Bosnia will not reach a natural equilibrium at which the fighting will stop. Nor will other areas of the former Yugoslavia remain quiet for long. It is likely that at least as many innocent people will die as have already died -- more than 200,000 -- and that the conflict will inexorably spread outside the former Yugoslavia.   Western leaders cannot pretend their policy failure is a success. Nobody, especially President Clinton, should think that because the West has abandoned Bosnia to partition the war will go away. The repercussions of inaction remain sobering. Here is a tour d'horizon and its likely development:

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
An Italian Restaurant Above the Crowd
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ZIO MICHEL, a two-year-old Italian restaurant in Cliffside Park, in Bergen County, stands out from the crowd in this area where Italian restaurants are as plentiful as barbecues in summer.

The tiny storefront, which seats no more than 58 people in quarters cramped enough to make changing seats hazardous, is owned by Michael Daniele, who used to be a chef at two large and well known restaurants, Archers in Fort Lee and Sonny D's in Secaucus.

nytimes_articles.headline: Confessions of a Rider On Metro-North   I laughed when I read Kate Stone Lombardi's article "A Who's Who of the Commute" (May 30) describing the four types of Metro-North commuters.   I was definitely a "worker" type. For three years, while I commuted from my home in Westchester to law school in Manhattan, "my" seat on the train was the one nobody wanted -- the windowless corner seat across from the bathroom. Yes, it had dim lighting, cramped leg space and the often unsavory odors emanating from the nearby lavatory. But to a law student it had the perfect combination of privacy and lack of distractions.
nytimes_articles.abstract: I rushed to that seat each morning. If, by chance, it was already taken, I walked from car to car until I found a similar seat -- usually with success. Having marked my turf by piling casebooks and notebooks on my lap and on the adjoining seat, I immediately went to work, praying that no one would be desperate enough to want a cramped seat with no window.   At each stop I pretended to be engrossed in my reading, hoping that my intense concentration would discourage even the bravest of commuters from interrupting me and asking that I remove 10 pounds of lawbooks from the seat. Yes, I was selfish. But we're talking law school here. Survival of the fittest.   After graduation from law school, I commuted all summer to a bar exam review course in Manhattan -- again, in my windowless corner seat. I was able to get two of the seven hours of daily studying done before I even got home.   After passing the bar exam, my commuting days ended. But I think fondly of my windowless corner seat, and wonder what desperate souls now covet its graffiti-covered upholstery. Thank you Metro-North. I couldn't have done it without you. MYLA BOOKBINDER BARRETT Scarborough

nytimes_articles.headline: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Kingston, R.I.; A Building For Nonprofits
nytimes_articles.abstract: A DOZEN nonprofit agencies now fully occupy a 38,000-square-foot office building completed last January on the University of Rhode Island campus here.    The agencies, which pay $8.16 a square foot in rent, share the costs of office equipment, utilities and other expenses and have a central conference room and a common phone bank for fund-raising to keep costs down.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sprays That Slay Plant Pests, Safely
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE nibblers and chewers are about, those pesky insects that make nasty holes and cause yellow spots in plant leaves. Gardeners everywhere usually like to get rid of these invaders as soon as possible.   But they like to do it safely. In these days of environmental awareness, many gardeners hesitate to use just any spray, but seek the least toxic method.

nytimes_articles.headline: LIFE REMAINS GRIM FOR THE ALBANIANS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tushe Xaka has lived all her 30 years in this village of 700 people, on a frighteningly winding, narrow dirt road along a deep gorge in the mountains 30 miles north of Tirana, the capital.    She has three children, could pass for double her age and owns only the clothes she wears. She goes barefoot to save her one pair of shoes, which she says she puts on only for high occasions, like funerals. She admits that sometimes, on harsh winter days, she has borrowed a pair from a neighbor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Israel Seeks to Keep North Korea From Aiding Iran
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although the countries have no diplomatic relations, Israel has quietly had a series of contacts with North Korea, hoping that a lure of economic cooperation may stop the Koreans from providing nuclear technology and a nuclear-capable missile to Iran, officials here say.    The missile, Rodong 1, also known as Scud-D, is still being developed. But Israeli officials have already expressed great concern because it is believed able to carry nuclear or chemical warheads and because, unlike earlier generations of the Scud, it has a stated range of about 600 miles and would put Israel within striking distance of missile sites in western Iran.

nytimes_articles.headline: Both Sides Now
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE CULTURE OF DESIRE
Paradox and Perversity in Gay Lives Today.
By Frank Browning. 
241 pp. New York: 
Crown Publishers. $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lyricist's Household A Blend of Cultures
nytimes_articles.abstract: MARGERY HARNICK was talking about her sea and skyscapes and the exotic handmade paper that textures her paintings.   Nearby, Sheldon Harnick was beaming at his wife's 16 watercolors now hanging in the C.F.M. Gallery on Greene Street in SoHo, her first extensive collection to be seen in New York City. Two Long Island exhibitions -- "more abstract and adventurous," Mrs. Harnick said -- are to open, one on Aug. 7 at the Benton Gallery in Southampton and the other on Aug. 21 at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton.   On a Wednesday afternoon two weeks ago Mr. Harnick was also edgy. The next night, "She Loves Me," the 1963 musical, was to open in a new production on Broadway. Two days later he felt bolstered by the sterling reviews that just might transform from cult to hit status a romantic musical set in a Budapest parfumerie in 1934.    Not that the lyricist of "Fiorello," which had opened four years earlier, and "Fiddler on the Roof," one year later, needs bolstering, but after 30 years it is nice to know that a favorite show's time has come.  Benefit Performance Saturday    Mrs. Harnick, an artist in ascent, and Mr. Harnick, who divide their time between an apartment on Central Park West and a house in East Hampton, will appear in "A Broadway Medley -- Hampton Style," one of 16 events next weekend on the South Fork to benefit Guild Hall in East Hampton.    In their hourlong performance at the house of Lillian Braude in East Hampton, the couple will include two selections from "She Loves Me" and two outtakes from "Fiddler on the Roof," "Dear Sweet Sewing Machine" and "The Butcher's Song." Their act is an outgrowth of a joint appearance at Rainbow and Stars in Manhattan several years ago.   "That was a nice detour," Mr. Harnick recalled. "But Margery needed to get back to art, and I wanted to go on writing."    Mr. Harnick's numerous works in progress include a 45-minute cantata, a full-scale version of "Cyrano" and a musical fantasy adapted from a Russian play.    "Sheldon's a good director," Mrs. Harnick said. "He knows the essentials he wants from the act."  Former Broadway Performer    Once a Broadway performer under the name of Margery Gray, she worked in two of Mr. Harnick's shows with scores by Jerry Bock, "Tenderloin" and "Fiorello." "But we weren't going out together then," she said. "We were married after 'Fiddler.' "   And then Ms. Gray appeared in, among others, "Tovarich," as the ingenue in the musical starring Vivien Leigh; "Drat, the Cat," as standby for Leslie Ann Warren, and opposite Hal Linden in a revival of "Anything Goes," but no longer in Mr. Harnick's shows. "Casts can be sensitive," she said, "and we didn't want it to seem like nepotism. So we kept our work apart."    After their marriage -- her second and his third -- Mr. Harnick said: "I respected Margery too much to say, 'I hope you give this up.' But I was delighted when she decided she wanted to be home, not rehearsing, or on the road."    They have a son, Matthew, a marine biologist in his 20's who lives in the Hamptons, and a daughter, Beth, from Mrs. Harnick's previous marriage. She is a songwriter in her 30's and lives in Los Angeles.   As a wife and mother who sometimes performed on commercials and voice-overs, Mrs. Harnick tried photography. Mary Rodgers and Tom Paxton, two neighbors in the Hamptons, bought her work, "but that wasn't hands-on enough," she said. Awaiting the "You're On" Call    "I grew up with a respect for art, and it was something to do in the dressing room while I was waiting to go on stage," Mrs. Harnick recalled. "My mother, Mildred Gray, was a fashion designer. She painted, and she's still at it at 88. While other kids had coloring books, she gave us drawing pads and unchewed pencils."    Musing on her creative beginnings, Mrs. Harnick said:   "All those years dancing in front of multimirrors in a rehearsal hall I was fascinated with the reflections' going out into space, the color play between light and people. I didn't realize that would grow into an obsession, and after I had done a piece of art, what an incredible revelation that I composed it, I lit it, I choreographed it. I did it all myself.   "My work is about nature -- wind, sunsets, things floating in water. People see different things in them, whatever they want it to be, but I know where I'm going before I put it together. It's as if the paper, paper so thin it's translucent when the light comes in, were the paint."    Mrs. Harnick uses paper made of papyrus, carrots, Japanese rice, eggplant from South America and bark from trees in California. "Beth sends those," she said.    On the harmony between greasepaint and watercolors in their lives, Mrs. Harnick said:   "We have a station wagon to constantly schlep canvases from New York to East Hampton. I have my own identity, and we do a lot of benefits. We get to rehearse together and laugh. It's the best of both worlds."

nytimes_articles.headline: A Village in the Palm of One's Hand
nytimes_articles.abstract:
OBABAKOAK
By Bernardo Atxaga.
Translated by Margaret Jull Costa.
326 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: Morningside Heights
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN a public relations move at the turn of the century, Morningside Heights was named "The Acropolis on the Hill." The name has stuck, at least among guidebook writers and the neighborhood's present enthusiasts.

 Then, as now, educational, spiritual and medical institutions dominated the neighborhood, occupying about half the land; one institution -- Columbia University -- owns another quarter.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chekhov in a Lifelike Setting
nytimes_articles.abstract: BEHOLD an esthetically correct "Cherry Orchard." In the Rushmore mansion at Woodbury in Orange County the audience regards Chekhov's powerless elite through an arched doorway, on a sprawling lawn and in a grand ballroom.   Liubov Ranyevskaya and her entourage sweep through a real library with a sculptured ceiling, brushing right by spectators seated on the aisle. When the actors are strolling or waltzing on the grass, the audience watches them through open French doors. Such stageless environmentally authentic productions bear the catch phrase "site specific." This one is site spectacular. One could do worse than take in Chekhov's last musings upon life and death on a summer night, on a real country estate, on 10 torchlighted acres, surrounded by some 500 more. Even when it is less than picture perfect, "The Cherry Orchard," in the second season of the Rushmore Festival of the Arts has three things going for it: location, location, location.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sonya Stevens, Michael Watts
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sonya Malynda Stevens, a daughter of Carol B. Stevens Eno of West Tisbury, Mass., and William H. Y. Stevens Jr. of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael John Watts, a son of Denise Russett of Litchfield, Conn., and William A. Watts of Manchester, N.H. The Rev. James Martin performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of West Tisbury.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Let the Pesticide Polluters Fool You; Clause Doesn't Work
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Michael Fumento (Op-Ed, June 9) calls for the removal of the Delaney Clause -- the provision of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act that prohibits the use as a food additive of any substance known to cause cancer in humans or in laboratory animals. His argument reflects the degree to which the Delaney Clause has become a symbol for what is wrong with the regulation of substances that may be hazardous to human health.   The most significant thing about the Delaney Clause is how little it matters. Since the Delaney Clause became law, no food additive has been removed from the market -- or even proposed for removal -- under its provisions that would not have been the subject of action under the general food safety laws.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Trolley Car Stages a Comeback
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT was a hot July morning in the 1920's, and 4-year-old Jeanette Nieciecka was bouncing on the wicker seat next to her mother as the packed Avenue C trolley threaded its way through Bayonne.

In the seats across from her, standing in the aisles and hanging off the running board were friends and neighbors, headed for the shops uptown, the county park or the ferries that would take them to work in Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline:
FOCUS;
A Golf Complex for Downtown Chicago
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A golf complex that includes a nine-hole course is coming to Illinois Center, 83 acres of offices, apartments and hotels that is perhaps the nation's largest downtown land-development project since World War II.

The huge development, bounded by South Michigan Avenue, East Randolph Street and East Wacker and North Lake Shore Drives, has been under development for 24 years, but 52 acres have yet to be built upon.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Steps Up Prosecution Of Sea-Dumping
nytimes_articles.abstract: For years, environmental groups and governments have been complaining about debris dumped from cruise ships that washes up on shores from the Caribbean to Alaska. Now something is being done about the problem. In April, Princess Cruise Lines pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Miami to discarding plastic garbage bags off the Florida Keys and paid a record fine of $500,000. A vigilant passenger with a video camera had recorded the incident.   Officials said the case marked the first successful prosecution of a cruise ship line in a United States court for violations in American waters of international agreements on marine pollution. Three other cases are being pursued in two Florida jurisdictions, thanks to a 1992 decision by the Coast Guard to stop relying on countries where cruise vessels are registered to carry out such prosecutions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wallpaper Removal Depends on the Paper
nytimes_articles.abstract: REMOVING wallpaper is always messy, but generally fairly easy. The methods depend on the type of wallpaper and the wall or ceiling material. The easiest to remove is so-called strippable paper.   To test removing it, try lifting the corner of a piece with a putty knife. If the corner comes away easily, peel the paper further by pulling it parallel to the surface, not outward. If the paper is strippable, entire sheets should be removable by this method.    Underneath may be a layer of backing paper. That can be left on the wall as a base for new wall covering, but if it comes away in places it has to be removed like ordinary nonstrippable wallpaper.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Living Downwind With Nowhere to Hide
nytimes_articles.abstract: American Ground Zero  The Secret Nuclear War  By Carole Gallagher  Illustrated. 427 pages. MIT Press. $39.95.   As you look at Carole Gallagher's powerful pictures and read her angry words in "American Ground Zero: The Secret Nuclear War," you may be reminded of James Agee's "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men," with Walker Evans's photographs of poor tenant farmers in the rural South during the Depression. But there's a big difference: the faces in the Agee-Evans book are lined with hunger and despair while the faces and bodies in Ms. Gallagher's book reflect animosity and irreparable nuclear wounds.

nytimes_articles.headline: Teacher's Showing of Anti-Abortion Film in Class Stirs Outcry
nytimes_articles.abstract: A teacher's decision to show an anti-abortion film to seventh-grade students has outraged some parents in this northern Westchester County community, igniting a debate about how public schools should address politically sensitive issues.   The Somers Central School District is weighing disciplinary action against the teacher, William Wienecke, who put aside his Civil War lectures on June 4 to show students in three social studies classes a documentary film with an anti-abortion message, including images of aborted and dismembered fetuses. The teacher did not offer an opposing viewpoint, said students in the classes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Douglas Lavin and Lisa Greenwald
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lisa Greenwald, a daughter of Beverly and Michael Greenwald of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas B. Lavin, a son of Carl and Dr. Audrey Lavin of Canton, Ohio. Rabbi Sue Ann Wasserman performed the ceremony at Columbia University's faculty house.   Ms. Greenwald, 29, is keeping her name. She is a doctoral candidate in European history at Emory University. She graduated from the State University at Binghamton, from which she also received a master's degree in comparative women's history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Allison Forester, Jeffrey Wintner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Allison Stacey Forester, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry J. Forester of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey M. Wintner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Wintner of Randolph, N.J. Rabbi Albert Raab performed the ceremony at the Brooklake Country Club in Florham Park, N.J.   The bride, 29, is to become an associate at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling in July. She and her husband graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, she magna cum laude and he summa cum laude. Both were elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'In a Dark Time'  Compagnie Ljada The Kitchen    Once "In a Dark Time" got going, it had nowhere to go.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Japan to France, a Bad Day for Free Trade
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last Friday was the worst day for the world economy since the invasion of Kuwait, perhaps since the 1973 Middle East war spawned a fourfold oil price rise. It was not just the day which saw the demise of the Liberal Democratic Party political machine tha

nytimes_articles.headline:
Enter, Summer;
A Catalpa Tree on West Twelfth Street
nytimes_articles.abstract:
While the sun stops, or
seems to, to define a term
for the interminable,
the human aspect, here
in the West Village, spindles
to a mutilated dazzle --
niched shards of solitude
embedded in these brownstone
walkups such that the Hudson
at the foot of Twelfth Street
might be a thing that's
done with mirrors: definition
by deracination -- grunge,
hiphop, Chinese takeout,
co-ops -- while the globe's
elixir caters, year by year,
to the resurgence of this
climbing tentpole, frilled and stippled
yet again with bloom
to greet the solstice:
What year was it it over-
took the fire escape? The
roof's its next objective.
Will posterity (if there
is any) pause to regret
such layerings of shade,
their cadenced crests' trans-
valuation of decay, the dust
and perfume of an all
too terminable process?

nytimes_articles.headline: Robin A. Shisler, Nolan D. Curtis
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robin Anne Shisler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron R. Shisler of Jenks, Okla., was married yesterday to Nolan David Curtis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolen D. Curtis of Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Belvedere Castle in Central Park.   Mrs. Curtis, 39, is the director of contractual relations for the concert division of the Nederlander theater organization in New York. She graduated from the State University at Buffalo. Her father retired as the principal engineer for the Town of Cheektowaga, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A2-11  THREAT TO BOLIVIA'S FOREST  The attention focused on the destrucTion of the Brazilian rain forest has overshadowed a similar problem in other countries, including Bolivia, where it is almost as severe.  A1  U.N. REVIEWING PEACE ROLE  The fighting between United Nations soldiers and a faction chief in Somalia and the failure of international troops as a buffer in Bosnia are forcing the organization to examine its role as a global peacekeeper. nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Femme Fatale Romances Her Prey In an Unusual Balanchine Work
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kinky ballet or ultimate metaphor for the human condition? "Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir," which the New York City Ballet revived superbly on Friday night as part of the Balanchine Celebration, raises questions that it barely seeks to answer. One of George Balanchine's most striking ballets, it is also among his strangest.   The scenery by Rouben Ter-Arutunian is the ballerina's costume. When Maria Calegari steps forward toward Jeffrey Edwards, writhing on the floor before her at the New York State Theater, she wears a giant black cape that begins to billow behind her. With relentless inevitability, the cloud of silk fills the stage, its changing shape controlled by the invisible stage hands who pull and release its five points of attachment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stolen Car Involved In a Fatal Accident
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 15-year-old boy, joy riding with two friends in a stolen car, rammed head-on into another vehicle yesterday, killing a 61-year-old woman and injuring her daughter, the police said.   The woman, Marie Bernard, died immediately, the police said. Her 20-year-old daughter, Yasmine November, who was driving their 1986 Chevrolet, was treated at Harlem Hospital Center and released.

nytimes_articles.headline: Circuit Rider Trying to Save That Old-Time Main Street
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Hersey is a modern-day circuit rider, going from village to village in the Catskill Mountains in an experimental program to revive the economic health of the Main Streets.   His official title is "Main Street Coordinator/Circuit Rider," but he describes himself as a catalyst, cheerleader, consultant and go-between for five communities trying to overcome the neglect and deterioration of their basic shopping streets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Stop the Roller Coaster
nytimes_articles.abstract: We have to cut out the business of pulling Bill Clinton up by the roots every week to see how he's doing.   "Another Failed Presidency"; "Incredible Shrinking President"; "What Went Wrong?" America went to the pollsters and delivered a ringing vote of no confidence; if this were Japan, we'd be holding new elections.

nytimes_articles.headline: Vanbiesbrouck Dealt, But He's a Draft Pawn
nytimes_articles.abstract: John Vanbiesbrouck did not wait by the phone yesterday, but, in his heart, he expected it to ring. It did.   Minutes before the 5 P.M. National Hockey League trading deadline took effect yesterday, the Rangers traded Vanbiesbrouck to the Vancouver Canucks for future considerations. Neither Rangers General Manager Neil Smith nor his Vancouver counterpart, Pat Quinn, would elaborate on what compensation the Rangers would receive.

nytimes_articles.headline: Norway Honors Grieg, Who Made Its Folk Tunes Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: Edvard Grieg (though he died in 1907) turned 150 on Tuesday night. And while the Norwegian Government has sponsored celebrations all over the world, the epicenter of the Grieg-quake was here in the city where he was born, where he lived much of his life and where he died.   Like Mozart at the kitschy height of the Herbert von Karajan era in Salzburg, Austria, with composer likenesses in every shop window, Grieg has been omnipresent during the 40th annual Bergen International Festival, which this year ran from June 2 to a gala Grieg concert on Tuesday night in the Grieg Hall, the city's concert facility. The gala, which took place in the presence of King Harald V, the "Royal Patron of the Grieg 150th Anniversary Celebrations," was telecast live to six countries and will be seen in taped and edited versions in many more.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "There is no awe in the letters. They just write 'Dear Bill and Hillary.' In the old days, if a letter came in addressed that way we automatically assumed that it was from a personal friend of the President's and we set it aside. But not now; they all think they're his friend." -- LILLIE BELL, who has been answering White House mail for 24 years.  [ A14:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Beating Is Suspected in Death of Woman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Firefighters, responding to a report of a fire in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday, discovered a 51-year-old woman, who had apparently been beaten to death, and her 45-year-old boyfriend, who had severe head wounds, police and fire officials said.    The woman, Pam Gibbons Hobbes, was found lying on the floor in a kitchen hallway of her smoky fifth-floor apartment at 61 Martense Street near Bedford Avenue in Flatbush, said a Fire Department spokesman, Francis McCabe. The man, Stanley Ziarno, who shared the apartment with Ms. Hobbes, was found lying on the floor of the bedroom.

nytimes_articles.headline: Health Agency Investigates Airplanes and TB Infections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Concerned that ventilation systems for airline cabins may contribute to the spread of contagious diseases, Federal health officials are investigating whether some passengers with tuberculosis have infected fellow passengers on long flights.   The Government is seeking to determine whether the recirculation of air in the cabins of airliners would allow the transmission of tuberculosis, a bacterial disease that is spread through the air by patients in the active stage of the disease. The disease caused three million deaths worldwide last year and infected eight million more people. Health officials say that worldwide 1 person in 3 is infected, although in the vast majority of those cases the disease is latent and cannot be transmitted.

nytimes_articles.headline: FIGHTING IN BOSNIA IS SAID TO RESUME
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fighting erupted in at least a half dozen places across Bosnia today, the third day of a cease-fire, and Bosnian Croat troop movements portended new hostilities in the central part of the republic, United Nations officials said.    Sarajevo radio reported that Bosnian Serbs continued to attack Muslim defenses around the eastern Bosnian enclave of Gorazde and that Bosnian Croat artillery had shelled the southern towns of Jablanica and Konjic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Mandela Walks a Tightrope Between Reality and Hope
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nelson Mandela's visit last year to the West African countries of Ghana, the Ivory Coast and Senegal was an expression of the pan-African spirit he has championed throughout his long career. But, as tonight's report on his trip, "The Last Mile: Mandela, Africa and Democracy," notes, the sort of democracy Mr. Mandela says he favors has not been much in evidence on his continent.   Colorful ceremonies and entertainments are interspersed with fragments of an interview with Mr. Mandela, who blames the repression and corruption in many African countries on colonial powers that did nothing to prepare people to govern themselves. Yet he says repeatedly that he sees "a definite movement away from authoritarian views to multi-party government."

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fire Wall Total Arts Festival  Irving Plaza 17 Irving Place Gramercy Park Through Sunday    The band had no name, and the piece had no title. Performance Space 122's Fire Wall Total Arts Festival opened last Monday night with two hours of free-form improvisation. Craig Harris, the trombonist and composer, assembled an eclectic all-star group that included the trumpeter Ahmed Abdullah, the alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe, the tenor saxophonist Chico Freeman, the bassist Jamaladeen Tacuma, the guitarists Elliot Sharp and Kelvyn Bell, the drummer Tony Lewis and the performance artist Laurie Carlos.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Relief, No Consolation for Saberhagen
nytimes_articles.abstract: The radar gun read 97. The scoreboard read 2-1. It seemed that straightforward for the Mets and Bret Saberhagen.   But this is the season spent in nonstop and out-of-control reverse. Nothing is straightforward. Nothing is simple. And there just aren't any triumphs.   Tonight, in the latest of what the club almost nightly terms its worst defeat of the season, Saberhagen and John Franco undid all that had been so magnificently put together over eight innings. The Pirates drove Saberhagen from the game in the ninth and then outwaited and outfought the club's closer to score a pair of runs and win, 3-2. Green's Gamble    Saberhagen, who had humiliated the Pirates for eight innings, scorching the plate's corners and reducing a handful of Pittsburgh bats to shards of wood around the batter's box, took the mound to start the ninth. It was his night. It would, the Mets trusted, end with his majesty.

nytimes_articles.headline: HBO Must Carry on Without Ashe
nytimes_articles.abstract: When HBO's Wimbledon coverage begins at 9 A.M. today, the crew will be without Arthur Ashe for the first time in 11 years. Ashe, who died of AIDS in February, brought his customary elegance and understatement to HBO. His was never a loud or brash voice, but an intelligent and restrained one, which mixed well with his rarely reticent colleagues, Jim Lampley and Billie Jean King.   Now, Ashe's spot will be taken by the Briton John Lloyd, whose experience as a tennis analyst is almost nil.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A2-11  THREAT TO BOLIVIA'S FOREST  The attention focused on the destrucTion of the Brazilian rain forest has overshadowed a similar problem in other countries, including Bolivia, where it is almost as severe.  A1  U.N. REVIEWING PEACE ROLE  The fighting between United Nations soldiers and a faction chief in Somalia and the failure of international troops as a buffer in Bosnia are forcing the organization to examine its role as a global peacekeeper.  A6

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in some editions of Business Day on Thursday, about the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation's agreement to buy KRTH-FM in Los Angeles, misstated the background.  Infinity will be the second broadcasting company in Los Angeles to take advantage of new Federal ownership rules that permit one party to own up to four radio stations in a metropolitan area.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Rock; Lollapalooza, Tattoos and All
nytimes_articles.abstract: Purple hair! Pierced lips! Tattoos! Souvenir T-shirts that cost $28! They were all on display in the audience for the Lollapalooza Festival, the third annual version of the alternative-rock showcase and package tour, which got under way on Friday afternoon at Thunderbird Stadium here. Primus, Alice in Chains, Dinosaur Jr., Fishbone and Arrested Development are the major names in a lineup that also includes seven other bands. But the audience is also an attraction, as fans in their teens and 20's look at themselves and test their self-image as a community.    Lollapalooza is becoming a habit: spring break for the alienated. In Chicago, a July 3 Lollapalooza show sold out before performers had been named. For anti-mainstream rockers, the festival combines stadium dates with some underground credibility. Audiences outside big cities can see headliners they've heard of and opening acts they may have heard about, without the age restrictions and late hours of rock clubs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankees Are Playing Like Bronx Bombers Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two rocket homers. Four doubles. Thirteen hits. All from one team. Eight of 10 non-pitchers got at least one hit. It was like T-ball -- at least for the Yankees -- where everyone gets at least one shot, just to be fair, just for the fun.   Sure, Bob Wickman was the starting pitcher and had a great game. But the offense drove in eight runs against the Minnesota Twins, and that cannot be ignored. Neither can certain individuals who have been especially productive lately.

nytimes_articles.headline: Azinger and Parry Still Aching for Major Victory
nytimes_articles.abstract: Paul Azinger and Craig Parry birdied the last hole of the United States Open today and finished tied for third, five strokes behind the winner, Lee Janzen, but they were both a bit crestfallen.   "I'm disappointed because the last two days I made some great putts that just hit the edge and didn't go in," Azinger said in front of his locker, after declining a request from the United States Golf Association for an interview in the press tent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: A top-ranked American women's team completed a highly successful Chinese tour earlier this month, competing in Beijing, Shanghai and Hongzhu. The high point, for Kathie Wei, Lisa Berkowitz, Lynn Deas, Beth Palmer, Carol Sanders and Betty Ann Kennedy, was a victory in the Beijing International Invitation tournament. The field of 24 teams included open squads from Hong Kong, other parts of China and the Far East, and one other American team. They also won a televised exhibition match against the national women's team of China.   Wei and Berkowitz recently formed a partnership that is working well. On the diagramed deal in the Beijing event they sat East and West, and punished a slightly unwary overcaller. North assumed that he could bid two clubs as a passed hand, but the sequel showed him the error of his ways.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; Wanted: A Million Black Republicans
nytimes_articles.abstract: Black Democrats in Congress are snarling at the White House and threatening an alliance with their Republican colleagues. Angry about the torturing of Lani Guinier, Representative Kweisi Mfume, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, has warned President Clinton that the caucus can harm as well as help this Presidency.   That's bad news for the beleaguered White House. But it's healthy for American politics. Too long have blacks behaved as the chattel of the Democrats, patronized by the party and written off by Republicans. A tryst between black Democrats and the Republicans won't change this equation. A movement of black voters to the Republican Party most certainly would.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Ballet Competition Tries To Quell Competitive Urges
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ballet competitions abound around the world, from Moscow and Tokyo to Varna, Bulgaria, and Jackson, Miss. At all of them, young dancers compete and judges present medals to the winners.   The fourth New York International Ballet Competition is a bit like that. Yet it is also different in a special way.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Math Test in New York Schools Penalizes Poor Readers
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In the hullabaloo over the results of the new math test in New York City public schools, no one has mentioned the major change in the test. It is now a reading test, consisting solely of 50 verbal problems to be done in less than 50 minutes. The math has not changed at all, but the children have to wade through a sea of language before they get to the math. Children who read poorly or slowly may never get to the math at all.   At my school, where the first language for most students is not English, our math scores used to be double our reading scores. Now they are just about the same.

nytimes_articles.headline: Officials to Meet With Union Today in Walkout by Staff at Homeless Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: Social-service officials in New York City are to meet this morning with a union representing workers at a center that places homeless people in shelters in an effort to end a staff walkout over safety concerns.    The center, at 78 Catherine Street in lower Manhattan, has been closed since Friday, when a caseworker was assaulted by a homeless woman. Over the weekend, the city bused homeless people to another placement office in the Bronx.

nytimes_articles.headline: Local Investment Helps the Economy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The Treasury Department should be applauded for looking at whether or not money market mutual funds and other financial service institutions should be covered by the Community Reinvestment Act, whose rationale is that financial institutions have an obligation to reinvest part of their funds in the communities from which their capital is drawn (Business Day, June 9). After all, money market funds offer deposit and checking services similar to those of banks, but money market fund operators do not incur the overhead of branch offices and full banking services. But several impressions you create should be corrected.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'True Love Waits' for Some Teen-Agers
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's awesome to be a virgin," said David Medford, who has just taken a pledge of sexual abstinence until marriage. "I want to give that as a gift to my wife. I want it to be special, not something I do just to fit in."   Mr. Medford, who is 17, and hundreds of other teen-agers here and around the country have recently signed pledges of purity as part of an abstinence program developed by the Southern Baptist Convention, church officials say.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the play "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me," STEPHEN REA wore shorts and sneakers. In the movie "The Crying Game," he wore the nondescript garb of an Irish Republican Army terrorist. So it comes as a bit of a surprise to see him turn up as a fashion model in the July issue of Gentlemen's Quarterly looking dapper, even with his hangdog facial expression, in lambskin jeans that cost $1,975, a wool sports coat ($2,225) and a white cotton shirt ($275), all by Hermes, accessorized by a $395 scarf from Barneys New York. And that's only one of four outfits in which he posed.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Poll, Whitman and Florio Within 5 Points of Each Other
nytimes_articles.abstract: The first public opinion poll since the gubernatorial primary shows Gov. Jim Florio with a five-point lead over his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, and the outcome of the November election hinging on the nine percent of the electorate that is still undecided.   The poll, conducted by The Star-Ledger of Newark and the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, found that if the election were held now, Mr. Florio would receive 48 percent of the vote and Mrs. Whitman would receive 43 percent.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Math Test in New York Schools Penalizes Poor Readers; Learning by Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Despite the declining math results in New York City public schools (news article, June 9), chess in the schools, a program aimed at student development in District 9 in the Bronx, is showing results.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Clannad  Beacon Theater    It is an amusing paradox that Clannad, an Irish folk band with a reputation for integrity, should have achieved its biggest success with a television commercial.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Sourpuss Steps Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Seth Greenberg had come to the courtroom of Judge Benjamin Wm. Mehlman this morning to plead his case, and it was not going well. Seems that on the evening of June 11, the village police, responding to a complaint that people were speaking loudly inside the house Mr. Greenberg was renting at 535 Bayberry Walk, issued him a summons for "shouting and yelling."   And now, Judge Mehlman was uttering the words that had fallen so heavily on so many ears over the years in this wary seaside community on Fire Island known better for its bylaws than its beaches. "I find you guilty," he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Janzen: Lucky and Good, Good And Lucky
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a tense, suffocating day that seemed too oppressive for great golf, Lee Janzen saved his absolute best for last today to win the 93d United States Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club.   Just when the 28-year-old Janzen had fallen into a tie with Payne Stewart with six holes to play and seemed ready to melt from the pressure and humidity, he responded like a champion.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Turkish Attacks : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK - The State Department issues information on despatches received from the American Minister at Teheran announcing that Turkish troops have seized the American and British consulates at Tabriz, and have pillaged the American hospital in the same t

nytimes_articles.headline: A Tokyo Pol, Once Out, Is Back Leading a Revolt
nytimes_articles.abstract: Six months ago, Ichiro Ozawa's political fortunes had ebbed so low that when accused of seeking intervention by organized crime in a prime ministerial race, he was reduced to defending himself by saying he had been at a key meeting where the plan was discussed, but only to serve drinks and empty ashtrays.   A political cartoon subsequently depicted him as a waiter in a bar fetching drinks for a gangster, who said to a friend, "Did you see who that was?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Vladivostok Journal; A New Capitalist Goes Foreign Shopping for Profit
nytimes_articles.abstract: With their easy banter, upscale clothes and shared bottles of imported vodka, the large group of young Russians on the eight-hour Moscow-to-Vladivostok flight were obviously people who did this often.   Halfway through the overnight flight, when most of his group had dozed off, Roman, the leader, agreed to explain who they were and what they did. It was a variation on a story often heard among Russian entrepreneurs trying to break out of the encrusted mold of socialism.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW AGE OF FUND RAISING FOR CATHOLICS   Brother Anthony Iazzetti's latest excursion into the world of raising money for his school in the north Bronx is far removed from the candy sales and raffles that have long been a staple of Roman Catholic fund-raising drives. To be exact, it's 2,786 miles away in Los Angeles. As the president of Mount Saint Michael Academy, he recently traveled to the West Coast to meet with a select handful of alumni who he hoped would become major contributors to the school's $6 million capital campaign. Although such efforts are not unusual for private colleges or universities, a growing number of Catholic high schools, and some grammar schools, have had to turn to an array of aggressive and sophisticated fund-raising techniques. A1. NEW YORK CITY  MEETING SCHEDULED IN WALKOUT   In an effort to end a staff walkout over safety concerns, social service officials are to meet with a union representing workers at a center that places homeless people in shelters. The center, at 78 Catherine Street in lower Manhattan, has been closed since Friday when a caseworker was assaulted by a homeless woman. The center usually serves about 75 families a day and is supposed to be open 24 hours a day. B2.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Old A-Plant, One Sure Thing Is the Volatility
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a windswept patch of desert plateau here, a barbed-wire fence surrounds the hole where workers are supposed to be building a factory to solve what could be the most serious environmental problem in the country.   The plant would take radioactive and explosive wastes from nuclear-bomb production out of leaking tanks and immobilize them in glass, which is relatively inert and hence better than liquid for such storage. But the plant is being delayed, so for now all the fence does is collect tumbleweed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Swell  CBGB    Two guitars, bass and drums -- the archetypal rock-band lineup -- gets a slight twist with Swell, a band from San Francisco that performed on Wednesday night. David Freel strums an acoustic guitar, while John Dettman usually plays electric slide-guitar lines. Mr. Freel's vocals are talky and deadpan; songs often use only two or three chords.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Saturday about a meeting between President Clinton and King Hussein of Jordan misstated the King's medical condition. He is in the United States for a follow-up examination; his treatment for cancer was last year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mail by the Millions Deluges The Clintons, Even the Cat
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bill Clinton has not reinvented government yet, but he has certainly revived one Washington institution: the United States Postal Service.    Since taking office, the President; his wife, Hillary, their daughter, Chelsea, and their cat, Socks, have received more mail than any other first family in history during the first five months: 3.5 million pieces, more than the Bushes received all of last year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abandoned Filipinos Sue U.S. Over Child Support
nytimes_articles.abstract: Next to her son James, what Lucia Villegas Hill prizes most may be a handful of documents identifying his father as an American sailor at the United States Navy base that shut down here last year.    "He's so far away now," she said, handing over a crinkled 1975 marriage certificate and a faded photograph of a man whose features bear some resemblance to her son's. It has been years since Mrs. Hill's husband wrote or sent money, and she clings to a scrap of yellow paper with his last known address and phone number, in Port Orchard, Wash.

nytimes_articles.headline: Debra Helfand and Jonah Klein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Debra Chana Helfand, a daughter of Sheldon and Helen Helfand of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonah Mitchell Klein, the son of Judith Pringle of New York and Richard Klein of Ithaca, N.Y. Rabbi Stuart M. Geller performed the ceremony at Fox Hollow, a catering hall in Woodbury, L.I.   Ms. Helfand, 25, is keeping her name. She is an editor in the office of publications at Columbia University, from which she received a master's degree in English. She graduated summa cum laude from Cornell University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her father is a lieutenant in Brooklyn with the New York City Police Department. Her mother is a senior library clerk at the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library in Woodmere, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Reported to Have A Brother He Never Met
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton has a half-brother he has apparently never met, The Washington Post reported today.   Birth records show that Mr. Clinton's natural father, William Jefferson Blythe, who died several weeks before Mr. Clinton's birth, was also the father of a son by another woman in the 1930's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Islanders Get Hextall And Deal Fitzpatrick
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the Islanders won the Stanley Cup in four consecutive seasons from 1980 through 1983, one of the big reasons was the play of Billy Smith. Smith was a combative netminder who didn't mind taking the occasional penalty by challenging opposing forwards who, he felt, took territorial or physical liberties near his crease.   In a major trade yesterday, the Islanders got another goalie in the Smith mold. He is Ron Hextall, a veteran acquired from the Quebec Nordiques in exchange for goalie Mark Fitzpatrick and a swap of first-round draft picks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Military's Zeal Decried in Sodomy Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a case that has drawn little public notice but has sent ripples through the Air Force hierarchy, an officer has been convicted of sodomy and another faces similar charges based solely on a gay civilian man's claim that they had sex with him.   The two officers, members of an elite transportation unit here, deny that they are homosexual and that they ever had sex with the man. The officers, Capt. Troy Carlyle and Capt. Luther Turner, say they are victims of a spurned friend.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wickman Is Buoyed By That Sinker Feeling As the Yankees Sweep
nytimes_articles.abstract: The baseball was accepted with humility. It was retrieved by Bob Wickman at the end of the game, the first complete game of his career, an 8-0 victory over Minnesota that finished a four-game sweep of the Twins. He plans to send the ball to his father in Wisconsin. For the sender, the significance ends there.   "I don't care about complete games," Wickman said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can We Make an Honest Man of the C.I.A.?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "C.I.A. Funny Businesses" (editorial, June 8): Perhaps less well known than the case of Erwin Rautenberg is that of Robert Maxwell, a former bank officer. In the mid-1980's, Mr. Maxwell handled letters of credit at First National Bank of Maryland for a Central Intelligence Agency proprietary company.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; The Price of Weakness
nytimes_articles.abstract: When I asked Cyrus Vance how he was feeling, I meant it as a telephone formality. But his answer was about Bosnia. "Sad," he said.    President Clinton had just signaled that he might accept a three-way partition of Bosnia, allowing Serbs to keep the fruits of their aggression. In light of all that had happened, I asked, was that now the best that could be done?

nytimes_articles.headline: Trial Explores Murky Lines of Authority at Bank
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Federal and state banking regulators met on April 23, 1981, at the Federal Reserve Board headquarters to consider an application from a group of Middle Eastern investors to take over a bank holding company in Washington, they wanted to know who would run the bank for its absentee owners.    The management issue was also very much on the minds of Clark M. Clifford and Robert A. Altman, the Washington lawyers representing the investors.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Route 66 Dance Company  Dia Center for the Arts    Ninotchka Bennahum and Suki John founded the Route 66 Dance Company with the idea of fusing ballet and modern, flamenco and Afro-Cuban styles to create what they call a cross-cultural language of dance. The company performed on Friday night in a program that suggested that such fusion can vitiate dance.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Math Test in New York Schools Penalizes Poor Readers; A Better Comparison
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 9 report on a decline in math scores in New York City public schools misrepresents the substantial achievements of the students. Since 1990, we have been upgrading our mathematics program to meet the higher standards developed by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. Those standards include reform of math testing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suzanne Rosenthal, Ryan Brackley
nytimes_articles.abstract: Suzanne Michelle Rosenthal, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Rosenthal of New York, was married yesterday to Ryan Walter Brackley, a son of Albert and Pat Brackley of Belle Harbor, Queens. The bride's uncle Louis R. Rosenthal, a former Kings County Criminal Court judge, performed the ceremony at the James Burden Mansion in New York.   Mrs. Brackley, 25, is a second-year student at Brooklyn Law School, from which her husband received a law degree. She graduated from Columbia University. Her mother, Barbara L. Rosenthal, is the president of B. L. R. Computer Consultants in New City, N.Y. Her father is an ophthalmologist in Garnerville and Nanuet, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Christopher St. Rebounds As Thriving 'Gay Mecca'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three years ago, times were tough on what has been called America's Gay Main Street. Along with the rest of New York City, the six-block-long mecca for homosexuals struggled to cope with the recession, inflated rents and the drug trade, which increased crime.   But Christopher Street in Greenwich Village had special problems, too: AIDS, which took its toll on the area's business owners and their clientele, and an upsurge in violence against homosexuals. Its longtime free-wheeling image drew drunken late-night crowds. More shops were vacant than anyone could remember, nightclubs languished and a vibrant street scene turned almost somber.

nytimes_articles.headline: PART OF THE UFFIZI IS BEING REOPENED
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alberto Ronchey, Italy's Minister of Cultural Affairs, said it brought to mind a speech by Winston Churchill: never, he half-quoted, had so few done so much for so many as had the staff of the Uffizi gallery in getting the museum ready to reopen today.    In a similar vein, Timothy Sean Kindle, a 26-year-old American with a backpack, thought it was "just awesome" to stand before Botticelli's "Birth of Venus" and see "something timeless like that."

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City Ballet  New York State Theater    Nikolaj Hubbe, from the Royal Danish Ballet, and Igor Zelensky, from the Kirov Ballet in Russia, have been adapting to the New York City ballet at their own pace since joining it last fall, and their debuts during the current Balanchine Celebration have evoked particular interest.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unrepresentative Press
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Mr. Clinton Picks a Justice" (editorial, June 15), you criticize President Clinton for his "intemperate response" to a reporter's question at a news conference following his nomination of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg to the Supreme Court. The reporter queried Mr. Clinton about the zigzag quality of his decision making. The criticism of the President was misplaced.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Yankee Organization Has an Organizer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Buck Showalter, the manager of the Yankees, sat at his desk one day last week, a good six hours before game time, juggling.   Juggling phone calls, lineup cards, coaches' inquiries, trying to track down elusive game film, line up scouts and make plans for a roster move necessitated by the return from the disabled list of Mike Witt, that evening's starting pitcher.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Zacharia, Mr. Paretzky
nytimes_articles.abstract: Karen Zacharia, a daughter of Don Zacharia and the late Judy Zacharia, was married yesterday to Raymond Paretzky, a son of Cicely Paretzky of Queens and the late Rabbi Martin L. Paretzky. Rabbi Irwin Kula officiated in Scarsdale, N.Y., at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Christina Zacharia.   Ms. Zacharia, who is keeping her name, is an associate in the Washington law firm of Williams & Connolly. She graduated summa cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received a law degree from Stanford University. Her father is a novelist and short story writer and the owner of Zachys Wine and Liquor Store in Scarsdale.

nytimes_articles.headline: Watson Recalls His Chip Shot
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tom Watson remembered. So did golf's historians.   Lee Janzen's chip shot into the cup on the 16th hole today assured him of victory at the United States Open and brought back a memory of another chip shot in another Open, 11 years ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Enter, Summer; Meditation on A Lawn
nytimes_articles.abstract: "All theory, dear friend, is grey . . ." -- Mephistopheles, in Goethe's "Faust" The blossoms fall of course and leave All our visible world to the Most unfruitful and discursive Totally theoretic green Speaking for all that can be seen, And for what that, unseen, occurs. What of the mellow, warm colors Trees reveal? When they come to grieve Over their early-fallen spring Then the ripe crops of outcrying Color from which we will gather Sad knowledge of our store of loss Will have borne fruit in disbelief -- The molding, model-building leaf, The clinging and insistent moss, The broadly speculative grass On which we think of something as Something else -- their time of the year Claims to be always. Now and here Greenness is abstractly severe: Green is as general as grey And the theoretical three Grey Fates who yet in this late day, Rational and silent and warm, Reign in practice in their sere Unflowered, fruitless theory Are gowned as in the uniform Of General June's green everywhere.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chicago Scores Its Biggest 3 of the Season
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Chicago Bulls have done it -- again and again and again. And by winning their third consecutive championship in dramatic fashion, they have established a place for themselves in basketball history.   With John Paxson making a game-winning 3-pointer and Horace Grant making a game-saving defensive play, the Bulls outlasted the Phoenix Suns, 99-98, in Game 6 of the National Basketball Association finals.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Swim, a Run, a Bike Ride and a Bump in the Road
nytimes_articles.abstract: It looked as if the thick clouds would shield the athletes from the heat at the Danskin Women's Triathlon this morning. But while the light rain provided some respite from the sun, it made conditions troubling to most of the 800 competitors and disastrous to Michellie Jones, causing the 1992 World Triathlon champion to slip off her bike and dash her hopes of winning.   As soon as Karen Smyers of Lincoln, Mass., crossed the finish line with a winning time of 1 hour 2 minutes 48 seconds and received congratulations, she said, "It's not a good way to win." She was concerned about her friend. Back Wheel Slips in Rain    Jones, an Australian who now lives in San Diego, completed the first leg of the race with a strong 750-meter swim and trailed only Alexandra Laws of Australia. Just as the athletes finished the swim, a steady rain began to make the bike route slick. Laws got a good start, but Jones struggled almost immediately.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perry Weiss, Jonathan Leviss
nytimes_articles.abstract: Perry Sondra Weiss, who plans to join the New York City Office of Management and Budget as a health-care budget analyst in August, and Jonathan Adam Leviss, a third-year medical student at New York University, were married yesterday. Rabbi Donald Rosoff officiated at the Charles Hotel in Cambridge, Mass.   Mrs. Leviss, 23, and her husband, 24, graduated from Tufts University, she magna cum laude, he cum laude. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Weiss of Sudbury, Mass. Her father is the administrator of the department of medicine at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wimbledon '93: The Tired, the Sick, the Injured Masses
nytimes_articles.abstract: Is this Wimbledon or Lourdes?   The famous grass courts, coaxed along by daily mistings, appear healthy enough to face a two-week pounding from the finest sneakers technology has to offer. But the owners of all this expensive footwear don't seem nearly as spry as the surface they're about to attack today when tennis' most prestigious Grand Slam tournament reinvents itself for another two-week run at the All England Club.

nytimes_articles.headline: Arrest in Slaying of Cabby
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Brooklyn man was arrested last night in the fatal shooting of a gypsy-cab driver during a robbery yesterday morning, the police said. Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman, identified the man as Clifton Davis, 31. The driver, Cilimon St. Louis of Crown Heights, was shot once in the chest after he picked up a man in Crown Heights about 6 A.M., the police said. Mr. St. Louis was at least the 20th cabdriver shot this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: PULSE: Parks and Recreation
nytimes_articles.abstract: Attendance at state parks fell in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last year, and parks officials blame an unusually rainy summer. Nevertheless, New York's state parks attracted more than 59 million visitors in 1992. And that, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a former minor league ballplayer, likes to point out, was more people than attended all major league baseball games that season.    The previous year, visitors to New York's parks had set a record of more than 63 million. Last year Niagara Falls surpassed Jones Beach as most popular of the Empire State's parks. New York offers 260,000 acres of state parks, as well as more than 6 million acres of state forests in the Adirondacks and Catskills. New Jersey's park system comprises 305,000 acres of state parks, forests, natural areas and historic sites, while Connecticut features roughly 173,000 acres of land in these categories.

nytimes_articles.headline: Term Limits Have Support of People Out of Office
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF proposed eight-year term limits were already in effect, the New York City Council President, most of the borough presidents and nearly half the Council members would probably be disqualified from seeking re-election this year.   Which is why a putatively populist crusade that could limit the discretion of elected officials and voters alike is supported largely by people who have been unable to win even one term or who have already held their jobs longer than the proposed limits would allow.

nytimes_articles.headline: Land Claim By Indians Is a Tactic In Casino Bid
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last November, when a tribe of fewer than 100 Indians filed a lawsuit staking a claim to the land that downtown Bridgeport stands on, many people laughed. Given the city's financial problems, some people joked that the Indians should just take it, while others wondered in jest whether Indians hadn't suffered enough.    The laughter stopped this month when lawyers for the tribe, the Golden Hill Paugussetts, announced they were expanding their land claims to include four Bridgeport suburbs -- casting a cloud over $10 billion in Fairfield County real estate. "I think we've gone from joke to nightmare," said Bernard Wishnia, the tribe's main lawyer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Frances Chan, Richard Allen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Frances Chan, a lawyer with the Internal Revenue Service in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Allen, the president of American Corporate Benefits Inc., an employee-benefits consulting company in New York. Justice Kristen Booth Glen of New York State Supreme Court officiated in her chambers in New York.   Ms. Chan, who is keeping her name, graduated from Smith College. She received a master's degree in management from the New School for Social Research and a law degree from New York Law School. She is a daughter of T. How Chan and Frank Chan, both of New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sniping Is Growing At The U.N. Over Weakness In Peacekeeping
nytimes_articles.abstract: The fighting between United Nations forces and a warlord in Somalia and the failure of international troops to be an effective buffer in Bosnia are forcing many to rethink the organization's vastly expanded role as a global peacekeeper.   Diplomats here have publicly complained of amateurism in the peacekeeping operations, with the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, asserting recently that "ill-equipped and often unprepared troops" are often sent into the field.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; Jazz at the White House (Home of a Serious Fan)
nytimes_articles.abstract: It had to happen, and when it did, it wasn't nearly as bad as it could have been. After President Clinton gave his final remarks tonight at the White House jazz festival, the saxophonist Illinois Jacquet handed him a saxophone, and off the band went into Miles Davis's blues waltz, "All Blues." Happy to say, the President (who in his early career as a saxophonist had committed Mr. Jacquet's landmark improvisation on "Flying Home" to memory), didn't equivocate, change his mind or buckle to pressure, though he did look a bit uncomfortable.   Then he unfurled a nicely formed improvisation that wasn't half bad, at least before it fizzled into silence. Deep in the dark recesses of the Presidential mind is clearly the knowledge, albeit a bit rusty, of what it takes to be an improvising musician. "Well, tunes in 3/4 time have a built-in rhythmic excitement," President Clinton said afterwards, casually.  "You just have to ride them."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bolivia's Rain Forest Falls to Relentless Exploiters
nytimes_articles.abstract: Almost daily here in Bolivia's dense Amazon jungle, above the sound of the rushing river, the squawking of macaws and the scolding of monkeys, the Mojeno Indians hear the buzz of chain saws slicing through six-foot-thick mahogany trees. Heavy machinery growls as it cuts 15-foot-wide paths through the forest and drags the majestic logs to collection sites where trucks take them to sawmills.   "We see the trails of the cutters all the time, almost wherever we go in the forest," said Esekiel Justiniano. He estimated that as many as 40 chain-saw gangs were cutting mahogany on the land given his tribe and three others by the Bolivian Government last year. The loggers are licensed to cut mahogany trees, but not on the Indians' territory.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Treasonous Talk : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - The Cocarde, which has accused so many men of treason, last night [June 21] accused M. Clemenceau of that offence. M. Edouard Ducret, its editor, says that the Parliamentary sitting two days ago at which M. Clemenceau was so badly used, was only t

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Team Has Speed To Burn in Germany
nytimes_articles.abstract: The team selected here to represent the United States at the World Track and Field Championships in Stuttgart, Germany, Aug. 13-22, is a relatively strong one, but there are some weak spots.   That is the opinion of both the men's and women's head coaches, who have spent the last five days watching athletes run, jump and throw their way onto the team through competition in the USA/Mobil championships.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Age of Fund Raising for Catholic Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: Brother Anthony Iazzetti's latest excursion into the world of raising money for his school in the north Bronx was far removed from the candy sales and raffles that have long been a staple of Catholic fund-raising drives. To be exact, it was 2,786 miles away in Los Angeles.   As the president of Mount Saint Michael Academy, he recently traveled to the West Coast to meet with a select handful of alumni who he hoped would become major contributors to the school's $6 million capital campaign. He had already done his research, thanks in part to a computerized data bank that provided him with details about the lives and careers of the school's alumni.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON BURMESE POLICY
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration is coming under growing criticism from human rights groups for its policy toward the military junta in Myanmar, formerly Burma, which they say is one of the most repressive governments in the world.   The groups say they are concerned that the Administration, out of deference to several of Myanmar's neighbors, mainly Thailand, is continuing restrictive policies toward Burmese refugees that were adopted in the Bush Administration. Some of the groups are also concerned over the Administration's support for an $18 million grant that was approved by a United Nations Development Program on Friday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Talking Sense to Ukraine
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ukraine is a sovereign state and will be treated like one by the United States. On that point Secretary of Defense Les Aspin left no doubt during his recent visit to Kiev. But as nationalists pressure Ukraine to keep its nuclear arms, doubts rise about what sort of sovereign state it intends to become -- one that lives up to its international commitments, or a nuclear outlaw that provokes a scramble for security in the region.    Washington can coax Kiev into making the right choice, but only if it adopts a new and comprehensive political strategy.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: WEEKEND Baseball  American League   CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Placed Damion Easley, second baseman, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 19. Recalled Rod Correia, infielder, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Traci Reisner, Daniel Merenstein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Traci Jill Reisner, a daughter of Mrs. Alvin I. Orlian of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Daniel M. Reisner, was married yesterday to Daniel Jon Merenstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel Merenstein of Pittsburgh. Rabbis Morton Gordon and Bernard Eisenman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Basket Gives Bulls Some Poetic Justice
nytimes_articles.abstract: Let history note that Michael Jordan had a supporting cast after all. Let this latest championship be remembered for one poetic verse of climactic team play.   Let that play be shown again and again, and its executors linked in partnership, in making the Chicago Bulls' case for greatness. Score it for the firm of Jordan, Pippen, Grant and Paxson.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AIDES SEE PROBLEM WITH VOW TO LIMIT WELFARE
