A 12th man who the authorities said acted as an enforcer for the organizers of the ill-fated voyage was also charged with trying to sneak the would-be immigrants into the United States, according to the indictment brought by Zachary W. Carter, United States Attorney in Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pope Endorses Bishops' Attempts To Rid Clergy of Child Molesters
nytimes_articles.abstract: In his first public statement on a problem that has shaken the Catholic Church in the United States, Pope John Paul II has told American bishops that he will help them use existing church law as far as possible to remove child molesters from the ranks of the priesthood.   In a letter released yesterday in Rome and Washington, the Pope told the bishops that he fully shared their sorrow and concern for the young victims "so seriously hurt by these misdeeds."  [ Excerpts, page A14. ]  And he said a committee of experts from the Vatican and the National Conference of Catholic Bishops would study how to apply church law, known as canon law, to the situation.  Shift in Attitudes    Six American cardinals recently traveled to Rome and asked the Pope directly for his help, several individuals familiar with the workings of the American church reported. The cardinals, they said, acted en masse after previous visits to Vatican officials by Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of Philadelphia did not produce any sign that church law might be adjusted or streamlined so that American bishops could act more swiftly and decisively against molesting priests.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Politics of Meaning : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Kelly's articles on Hillary Rodham Clinton (May 25 and 26) and her "politics of meaning" missed the point. First, the evolution of Mrs. Clinton's political philosophy and the fact that she is a child of the liberal generation do not in

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; The Trade in Spies: Not All Black or White
nytimes_articles.abstract: Spy Trader  Germany's Devil's Advocate and the Darkest Secrets of the Cold War  By Craig R. Whitney  Illustrated. 375 pages. Times Books. $25.   The cold war gave the world not just heroes and villains, but also a gray supporting cast of spies, middlemen and mercenaries who lived and operated in the shadows. Of these, few are as intriguing as Wolfgang Vogel, the mysterious East German lawyer who, during the three decades the Berlin wall stood, quietly brokered the clandestine exchange of spies and the ransom of some 30,000 political prisoners from East Germany and the Soviet bloc. This unsavory business netted the Communists billions of dollars and made Mr. Vogel one of the richest and most influential private citizens behind what was once called the Iron Curtain.

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'L'Elisir d'Amore'  Metropolitan Opera in Prospect Park    Opera in the park is startling enough, but bel canto on a Brooklyn ball field: that's entertainment. "L'Elisir d'Amore" is one of two concert productions that the Met is taking to various parks around the New York area; Beautiful Prospect Park was the host on Wednesday night. The sun set over the darkening woods; candles glowed among picnic spreads; dogs pricked up their ears; policemen grumbled about missing the Suns-Bulls game; a nearby group of soccer-playing youths looked on in bewilderment ("What are they doing over there?"). Amid all this the first strains of Donizetti sounded a bit unreal, but the music seemed to stretch itself and fill the space.

nytimes_articles.headline: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Ervin Staub; Studying the Pivotal Role of Bystanders
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT was the summer of 1944, and 6-year-old Ervin Staub and his family, like other Jews in Budapest, were being set apart from their neighbors by laws imposed by the Nazis. Food was strictly rationed, and Ervin's 13-year-old cousin Eva, desperate to get a loaf of bread for her family, was waiting in a long bakery line after the curfew for Jews and without the yellow Star of David she was supposed to wear.   "Someone pointed her out as a Jew, and three young thugs tried to take her away," said Dr. Staub, now a psychologist at the University of Massachusetts, who vividly recalls the incident. "But she ran into our house to hide, and my aunt yelled at the thugs with such defiance that she scared them away."

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Looks to Conference Panel to Restore Budget to His Liking
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton and his top aides spent the day whipping up citizen support for his five-year, $500 billion budget package, but not entirely out of fear about its chances in the Senate.   To the contrary, Democrats are confident that the Senate will pass the plan after it is introduced on Wednesday.   They are less certain about their prospects in the legislative conference that follows, which promises to be a drawn-out effort to fuse the Senate's bill and the more liberal version that the House passed last month.

nytimes_articles.headline: 4th Endeavour Flight Pursues European Satellite
nytimes_articles.abstract: The space shuttle Endeavour and its crew of six bolted into the sky in a hail of fire and smoke today on a mission to retrieve an orbiting European science laboratory and to practice space-walking techniques.   After lifting off at 9:07 A.M., about 22 seconds late after an unidentified small aircraft appeared to intrude into restricted airspace near the Kennedy Space Center, the Endeavour pierced a cloud bank and began a three-day orbital chase to track and catch the satellite.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q&A
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Cooling Fan   Q.  Do fans actually make a room cooler?    A.  They can, but their main influence on rendering a stifling room bearable is probably on the individual perspiring body in the room, said Dr. David Goodstein, vice provost and professor of physics and applied physics at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, Calif.

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Memo; Shades of Perot: Parties Go For the Grass Roots
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sometimes loudly, sometimes quietly, Republicans and Democrats are grousing about Ross Perot at every turn. But they are not reluctant to imitate him.   Six months after Mr. Perot proclaimed the formation of his own grass-roots organization, the Republican Party announced today that it was doing the same thing, and that its group would use the same kind of public opinion surveys the Perot group does. Not to be left out, the Democratic Party is establishing its own group that may even have a toll-free telephone number, a la Perot.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trottier Leaving Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bryan Trottier's return to the Islanders as an executive appears to be over. The team has called a news conference today on Long Island and is expected to announce that Trottier will return to the Pittsburgh Penguins, this time possibly for a playing comeback or for a management position.   Trottier, who broke in with the Islanders in 1975, played 15 seasons in New York before joining the Penguins in 1991 for two more years. After announcing his retirment last summer, he rejoined the Islanders as a vice president.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; It's A Pandemic
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. W.C.T. of Otisville, N.Y., has a grievance against "names." They don't answer his letters. He has sent me a letter complaining about it.   What Mr. W.C.T. means by "names" is that small group of Americans who do all the talking, or writing, or performing, or bossing. Then there are "ordinary" people, meaning people who get the epistolary cold shoulder from the "names." Or as Mr. W.C.T. puts it:

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. MAY LET HANOI GET I.M.F. FUNDING
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's senior foreign policy advisers have concluded that the Administration should no longer attempt to block loans to Hanoi from the International Monetary Fund, senior Administration officials said tonight. The recommendation could presage an easing of the relationship between the United States and Vietnam.   In a meeting last week, members of the National Security Council decided to recommend to the President that the United States raise no objections to a plan by France and Japan to pay more than $140 million in arrears that Hanoi owes to the fund. Such an action would free the monetary fund to approve new lending to Vietnam during its next board meeting in July.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  National League   CHICAGO CUBS -- Signed Gamalier Castro and Daniel Gil, pitchers; Brett McCabe and Kevin Orie, infielders; and Vee Hightower and John Sauer, outfielders. International Baseball Association   IBA CONGRESS -- Elected Aldo Notraui as president; Richard Case as secretary general; Mark Marquess to the technical commission; Neil Lantz to the legal commission; and Warren Turner to the youth commission.

nytimes_articles.headline: Empire Blue Cross Says It Paid Claims Without Checking Them
nytimes_articles.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield routinely paid claims from doctors, hospitals and pharmacies without any attempt to determine whether the claims had already been paid or might be fraudulent, company officials acknowledged yesterday.   The officials decided that it was cheaper simply to pay the claims than to program their computers to check them. A memorandum, prepared in February by the head of internal audits for Empire, made an urgent appeal to change and upgrade the computer system. Empire provided the memorandum yesterday in response to a request from The New York Times.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of a production error, an article about a renewal of fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina was omitted from some copies yesterday, and an outdated article, from the previous day, appeared under its headline.  Readers wishing copies of the correct article, carrying the dateline "June 20," may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Lena Horne and the Stuff of Legend
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lena Horne gave a performance at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening that should become legend. She was the top-billed musician in the JVC Jazz Festival's tribute to Billy Strayhorn, and she reduced the audience to shivers with the story of how she met the composer and arranger who was Duke Ellington's musical right arm. Then, in rivetingly energized performances of several Strayhorn songs topped off with a fiery rendition of "Stormy Weather," she brought the audience to its feet. It was an accomplishment that few performers could have carried off at any age, let alone at 75.    Her first meeting with Strayhorn was in 1942 in California, she recalled. She was sitting in a theater feeling lonely when she was approached by "a beautiful brown boy in big horn-rimmed glasses, who looked like a lovely brown owl." He had been sent over by Ellington to see if she wanted something from the refreshment stand.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Jurassic Park' Won't Turn Kids Against Science
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I believe that "Evil Science Runs Amok -- Again!" by Carol Muske Dukes (Op-Ed, June 10) misses the point in arguing that from "Frankenstein" to "Jurassic Park" popular entertainments have made us fearful of science.

nytimes_articles.headline: Well, at Least He Didn't Spit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Knoxville Smokies Manager GARTH IORG and pitcher TRAVIS BAPTIST were ejected from a 3-2 Southern League loss to Chattanooga.   What was their sin? Did they curse the umpires? Kick dirt on the plate? Chase a heckler in the stands? None of the above.   Baptist was chewing tobacco in the dugout on Sunday. Iorg was chased for not stopping him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; A Family Battles Incest's Taint, and the Dangers of a Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: One for the My-How-Times-Change Department. Back in 1984, "Something About Amelia," a television movie starring Ted Danson and Glenn Close, created a stir and drew hefty ratings as it very carefully explored what was then the explosive subject of incest. Now, after Donahue, Oprah, Geraldo and other talk-show hosts have tramped through the same subject for years, incest is something of a television staple.    The latest example, a television-film import from Canada, can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 2. Written by Nancy Isaak and directed by Jorge Montesi, "Liar, Liar" begins as a portrait of the close-knit Farrow family whose only disruptive member appears to be an 11-year-old daughter named Kelley (Vanessa King). A spirited girl, she has a reputation for exaggerating and making up stories. Her dad, Gil (Art Hindle), an unemployed shipbuilder, swerves between disciplining Kelley harshly for various infractions and assuring her that she is, as his favorite song puts it, "my special angel."

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Jurassic Park' Won't Turn Kids Against Science; Biotechnology's Uses
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   You ask, "Should We Revive The Dinosaurs?" (editorial, June 13). Aw, I don't know. Maybe we can get those "arrogant, unscrupulous and unthinking scientists" that Steven Spielberg portrays so well in "Jurassic Park" to concentrate instead on unicorns or pigs with wings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Filadelfia Journal; The Godly Make Paraguay's 'Green Hell' Bloom
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a seasonal water hole north of here, a cowboy recently came across a stand of ancient bottle trees, so called because their pear-shaped trunks were believed to contain water.   In the shade of the thorn-covered trees, he found rotting cartridge belts and rusting canteens, reminders of 5,000 Bolivian soldiers who gathered at the water hole, only to die of thirst.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trenton Authorizes a $15.4 Billion Spending Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Legislature today passed a $15.4 billion budget for fiscal year 1994 that includes a $150 million reserve fund that has become the focal point of election year debate.   The budget also includes $25 million in anticipated revenue from a retaliatory commuter tax on New Yorkers, which a decision today by the United States Supreme Court guaranteed can be legally collected.

nytimes_articles.headline: Turning to the Garden, Rural India Heals Itself
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tulasia Row is very ill. The one-year-old, his emaciated body resting in his mother's arms, is in danger of succumbing to the biggest killer of Indian infants, diarrhea. Then Vijaya Kumari - a local representative of ASHA, a private voluntary group that

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sixty years ago an aggressive player like the world champion, Alexander Alekhine, steered away from symmetrical positions because he believed they were conducive to draws. If the opponent has everything I have, how can I claim to have any advantage and justify playing to win? But nowadays there are ways to combat the sterility of symmetry.   For one thing, today's players are ingenious in finding moves that cannot be copied and, in fact, few games continue for very long if Black can maintain an arid balance of position. White's advantage of moving first is the key to avoiding symmetry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let Sleeping Subs Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Apathy Above, Terror Below" by Igor Spassky (Op-Ed, June 3) is sensationalizing and wrong to argue for raising the submarine Komsomolets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Birds With Attitude
nytimes_articles.abstract: They first noticed something amiss when a bird whizzed by their heads about three weeks ago, so close it nearly touched them. Now every time they venture onto their Manhattan rooftop, they're dive-bombed. It's gotten so bad that when a neighbor goes out onto his terrace one floor below, he's attacked too.   The birds are aggressively defending their space, not to mention the next generation. They've built a nest, and turned the rooftop into forbidden territory, making it impossible to tend the plants, pick the few struggling roses, enjoy the water-tower view. They've even intimidated the cat, an old, deaf calico that just wants to stretch in the sun.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rostropovich and Johns Win Awards
nytimes_articles.abstract: The painter Jasper Johns and the cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich are among the five winners of the 1993 Japanese Praemium Imperiale awards for lifetime achievement in the arts. The prize winners were announced yesterday in Berlin by Helmut Schmidt, the former West German Chancellor.   Each winner is to receive $138,000. The others named are the French choreographer Maurice Bejart, the Swiss sculptor Max Bill and the Japanese architect Kenzo Tange.

nytimes_articles.headline: Columbia Ponders The Fate Of 'Hero'
nytimes_articles.abstract: A producer at Columbia Pictures didn't show up for work today because, he said, the atmosphere was just too poisonous. At breakfast this morning at a Beverly Hills hotel, an agent glanced down at her shredded wheat and whispered, "There are a lot of depressed people at Columbia." By lunch time, the questions all over town were: Who's to blame? Who's the fall guy?   Although it's far too early to call "Last Action Hero" a flop, Columbia's super-hyped, super-expensive Arnold Schwarzenegger adventure fantasy seemed, to most Hollywood executives, the summer's financial disappointment, grossing only $15.3 million in its first weekend. In contrast, Steven Spielberg's dinosaur adventure, "Jurassic Park," grossed a record $50.1 million in its first weekend and $38.5 million this past weekend, its second.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; 'Camelot' Returns With Goulet as King
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the first Broadway musical by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe after "My Fair Lady," "Camelot" was as highly anticipated as a coronation. At the time, the advance sale was the largest in Broadway history. The 1960 musical, which turned out to be the last Lerner and Loewe theatrical collaboration, has grown in stature over the years, primarily because of its superb score.    Drawing upon themes from T. H. White's "Once and Future King," the score combined a lyrical simplicity with a lush romanticism, beautifully captured in numbers like "I Loved You Once in Silence" and "If Ever I Would Leave You." These ballads sung by Guenevere and Lancelot are among the most memorable in the Lerner-Loewe catalogue. King Arthur supplies the wit, with songs like "I Wonder What the King Is Doing Tonight." Subsequently, the title song joined Arthurian legend with American political mythology.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: There is some pretty impressive artwork hanging on the walls in United States embassies abroad, and now in the residence of MADELEINE K. ALBRIGHT, American delegate to the United Nations, at the Waldorf Towers as well.   Tonight she's giving a party at her official residence there to celebrate the Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies foundation and the 21 artists whose works have been donated to a new collection for her walls. They include Willem De Kooning, Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Roy Lichtenstein, Claes Oldenburg and Frank Stella.

nytimes_articles.headline: Patriots' Running Back Out of Hospital
nytimes_articles.abstract: New England Patriots running back LEONARD RUSSELL was released from Massachusetts General Hospital, three days after he was hospitalized with stab wounds in the chest.   Russell, 23, was stabbed early Friday after getting into an argument outside a nightclub. The police said yesterday they have identified a suspect but still haven't made any arrests.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Is Seeking to Disband Town's Private Police Force
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey state lawyers plan to go to court on Tuesday to try to force tiny Sussex Borough to disband its uniformed security force, which looks like a regular police department but, by law, cannot function like one.   Robert T. Winter, the director of the State Division of Criminal Justice, said the municipality's security guards have no more enforcement powers than "everyday citizens" and could pose a danger to themselves or the public if they try to act as police officers.
